document.docTitle: Cedrimyia margareti Namayandeh & Hudson 2022, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Two new Orthocladiinae (Diptera: Chironomidae) collected in overlooked places of Midwest USA

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new Orthocladiinae (Diptera: Chironomidae) collected in overlooked places of Midwest USA

Etymology. The new species is named in honor of Margaret Hudson, who has been a great help in collecting type specimens, making this study possible.
Total length 2.8â€“3.2, 2.9 mm . Wing 2.3 mm long and 0.65 mm wide.
Coloration of mounted specimen . Head, thorax, halter brown. Legs and abdomen light to golden brown. Wing light to golden-brown

Head ( Fig. 1a ). Antenna with 12 flagellomeres, last flagellomere with 8 sensilla chaetica, 2 nd â€“3 rd segments each with 2 sensilla chaetica, groove starts at 3 rd segment, AR 1.3â€“1.4. Eyes bare, with wedge-shaped dorsomedial extension. Temporal setae 9â€“10, including 3 inner verticals, 3â€“4 postoculars and 3â€“4 outer verticals. Tentorium narrow with small tentorial pit close to apex ( Fig. 1a ), tentorium 135â€“156, 146 Î¼m long. Clypeus rectangular, 87 Î¼m long and 116 Î¼m wide, bearing 5â€“7, 6 setae, setae 77â€“85, 80 Î¼m long. Palpal segments lengths (in Î¼m): 44â€“54, 50; 50â€“61, 57; 73â€“99, 81; 83â€“90, 85; 127â€“156, 148. Third palpomere with 1 sensilla clavata.

Thorax ( Fig. 1b ). 2 scalpellate acrostichals in centre of scutum. Dorsocentrals 5â€“7, 6 in single row, prealars 2â€“3, scutellars 4 in single row. Humeral pit small. Antepronotal lobes developed, narrowing anteriorly, without gap and bare.

Wing ( Fig. 1c ). Brachiolum with 2 setae. Squama with 5 setae. R with 5 and R 1 apparently bare, other veins without setae. Costa extended, extension 69 Î¼m. R 4+5 ends just above M 3+4 . Anal lobe squared. Microtrichia visible at> 100 x magnification.

Legs . Mid and hind tibia with long sparse beard, hind femur with keel. Pulvilli absent. Fore tibia spur 43â€“53, 47 Î¼m long, mid tibia spurs 24â€“25; 18â€“23, 20 Î¼m long, hind tibia spurs 44â€“51, 48 and 15 Î¼m long, hind tibia comb with around 12 spines. Lengths and proportions of legs as in Table 1 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Male leg lengths (Î¼m) and proportions of
Cedrimyia margareti
gen. n. sp. n.

subSubSection.paragraph: Hypopygium ( Fig. 1d ). Tergite IX with curved ridge running close to mid-section of anal point. Anal point narrowly triangular, long, reaching close to the apex of inferior volsella, bearing around 6 simple, short, and weak setae, distributed evenly along its mid-section, and pointing posteriorly, apex rounded; anal point 75â€“97, 84 Î¼m long and 27â€“32, 29 Î¼m wide. Virga present consists of two long spines, 50â€“54, 53 Î¼m long. Sternapodeme straight and thick, 65â€“73, 69 Î¼m long. Phallapodeme collar bone-shaped, 72â€“86, 81 Î¼m long. Inferior volsella a prominent triangular lobe. Gonostylus squat-shaped, well expanded in mid to anterior section, surface with 3â€“4 strong, comparatively darker, spine-like setae; crista dorsalis developed, thin and blade-like, stretching from mid to anterior of gonostylus; gonostylus 65â€“75, 69 Î¼m long. Gonocoxite 181â€“194, 188 Î¼m long. HR 3, HV 3.
Total length 2.0â€“ 2.1 mm . Wing 2.1â€“2.4, 2.2 mm long and 0.76â€“0.86, 0.80 mm wide.
Coloration of mounted specimen . Head, thorax, halter brown. Legs and abdomen light to golden brown. Wing light to golden-brown

Head ( Fig. 2 a-b). Antenna with 5 flagellomeres, last flagellomere with 10 sensilla chaetica, 3 rd â€“4 th segments each with 2 sensilla chaetica ( Fig. 2a ), AR 0.5â€“0.6. Eyes bare, with short dorsomedial extension. Temporal setae 5, including 1 inner verticals, 1 postoculars, 2 orbitals and 1 outer verticals ( Fig. 2b ). Tentorium long and narrow with small tentorial pit close to apex, tentorium 126â€“149, 137 Î¼m long. Clypeus rectangular, 89 Î¼m long and 109â€“127, 118 Î¼m wide, bearing 5 setae, setae 88 Î¼m long. Palpal segments lengths (in Î¼m): 44â€“52, 48; 49â€“55, 52; 82â€“84, 83; 77â€“84, 80; 138â€“154, 146. Third palpomere with 1 sensilla clavata.

Thorax . 2 scalpellate acrostichals in centre of scutum. Dorsocentrals 5â€“6 in single row, prealars 2, scutellars 4 in single row. Humeral pit small. Antepronotal lobes developed, narrowing anteriorly, without gap and bare.

Wing ( Fig. 2c ). Brachiolum with 2 setae. Squama with 5 setae. R with 6â€“10, 8, R 1 with 2â€“3 setae, R 4+5 with 2â€“3 setae, other veins without setae. Costa extended, extension 137 Î¼m. R 4+5 ends just above M 3+4 . Anal lobe squared. Microtrichia visible at> 100 x magnification.

Legs . Mid and hind tibia with long sparse beard, hind femur with keel. Pulvilli absent. Fore tibia spur 22â€“30 (26) Î¼m long, mid tibia spurs 22â€“25, 23; 21â€“22 Î¼m long, hind tibia spurs 38â€“52, 45 and 22 Î¼m long, hind tibia comb with around 12 spines. Lengths and proportions of legs as in Table 2 .

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. Female leg lengths (Î¼m) and proportions of
Cedrimyia margareti
gen. n. sp. n.

subSubSection.paragraph: Ecology and habitat. Adults of the species were collected in the vicinity of Queer Creek just below Cedar Falls and along Superior Harbor in Lake Superior, vastly different habitats. Queer Creek is a third-order stream running through a deep ravine with rugged sandstone cliffs covered in part with lichen and with numerous seeps. Superior Harbor is part of a highly modified St. Louis River estuary for maintaining a safe harbor for both Great Lakes and international shipping. Extrapolating from these suggests that the habitat for this new genus is probably not truly aquatic but is presumably decaying moist organic matter along the shores of these two habitats. It is likely that the high organic (humus) soil of this region provides an ideal habitat for terrestrial Chironomidae . In East Fork Queer Creek, Ohio , close to our sampling location, Bolton and Jacobsen (2010) previously found close to seven species of terrestrial Chironomidae . The presence of emerging adults in May and again in October indicates that this species has more than one voltine.
